instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message:
we have a board with <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> dead. some burning traces are on pins 38 and 39.
lost DZ6704 and DZ6705

I repair the area and change the two DZ and I changed and repair the area of the <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>.

Now we have sound (chime) on the boot and immediately a "crash sound" after the chime like a disconnection. And on the OS X there are no sound card just the spdif outpout.

We don't now how to find the problem. Thanks to help us :-)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: this could be a bad headphone jack, do you have sound on headphones??, remove <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> and check if sound comes back...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message:
No. Same problem
......." TAC ! Chime ! TAC ! "

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: Sounds like a 4.5V analog issue. Check output from <CHIP>U6200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message:
always the same problem. The output was ok on <CHIP>U6200</CHIP> and I test all pin on the <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> .
Does it possible to test the jack ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: Audio jack will not cause distortion on audio through speakers. Is the 4.5V getting to <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>? Are all other supply voltages getting to <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>? Was <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: i have 0v on <SIGNAL>CS4206_VREF_ADC</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: I'm not sure what that should be but it seems to be for A/D conversion which would be tied in with the 4.5V supply. I still have no clear answer if you have 4.5V on pin 24,25 <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: Does it possible that the problem was on the CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: Oh my god, please answer the questions asked...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message:
Yes sorry the 4.5v was on the pins 24 and 25

perhaps the <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> was the problem ? Does it possible to test it ? or does it possible to disconnect it and what we can see in this case on OS X ? I find this logic board with dead  DZ6704 and DZ6705 and output 38 and 39 of the <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> and the <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> was on the way

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> and see if audio works on speakers again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: I find the pin 2 of the <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> disconnected. So the test was the same and I solder this pin but it is the same result. A "slash" or "tac"before and after the bip sound when I don't place DDR or before and after the chime  :-(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message:
I do not quite understand what you mean. You can leave <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> out, it is only needed for SPDIF and no one uses this. Can you make a video of this "sound"?
Does audio work in OSX with <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> removed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message:
I have replaced the <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> and removed the <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> and the result was the same.
for the video I have a message here "invalid file". And same message with just audio :-(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: Upload to youtube or google. The forum does not support such large files.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: here :

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: It is possible that <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> is pulling down the REF voltage for <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>. Is there low resistance/short on <SIGNAL>HPAMP_REF</SIGNAL>. You can remove <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> too, just a mic will not work anymore but who cares about that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message:
I found 64kohm on <SIGNAL>HPAMP_REF</SIGNAL>. I have remove the <CHIP>U6400</CHIP>.

no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message:
I have changed the J6700 and under this I found a hole on the circuit board. I have repaired the circuit for this J6700 and replace the J6700. Now I have the sound on the left and right channel on the head set or on the MBP speakers but I found the same problem on the start and the stop of the sound playing. "Tchak...... tchak"

Other ideas please. 

and thanks for all. I am just a junior :-)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: What kind of "hole". It is very possible that if the board was burned that there is some kind a short inside the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message:
and does it possible to find the internal board view ?

The first problem was a high Courant gone through the jack connector. I don't know how but it is clearly the first problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound problem
threads.message: Nope, there is no "internal" board view. If you really have time to waste you can dig into a donor board and see what is there. But this is just not a feasible repair for a single repair.
